newsitem.title: ITALY: St Lucia takes banana row to food summit.
newsitem.headline: St Lucia takes banana row to food summit.

text.p: The tiny Caribbean island of St Lucia, embroiled in a banana export row with the United States, appealed to a world food summit on Thursday to help fight against "unwarranted economic aggression".

Agriculture minister Ira d'Auvergne told delegates in a speech at the summit that his country was awaiting a World Trade Organisation (WTO) panel report into the dispute but that the panel was "heavily weighted against us".
He said countries like St Lucia felt abandoned by former friends and left to wonder whether they had become the "forgotten ones in the global political game."

St Lucia is one of a group of small banana-producing countries in Africa and the Caribbean which export to the European Union under preferential rates and are involved in a complaint before the WTO brought by the United States.

The United States -- backed by four Latin American countries including Ecuador which is the world's leading banana exporter -- argues that certain aspects of the arrangements are violations of WTO agreements on open trade.
D'Auvergne said certain nations were implementing trade policies to undermine the economies of small island states like his by depriving them of markets for traditional exports.

"Those nations together with the multinationals whose interests they promote demonstrate not only a callous disregard for the mission of this summit...but seek by their actions to dislocate our fragile economies," he said.
"The international community should not sit idly by whilst our small helpless countries continue to suffer from this unwarranted economic aggression," he said.
D'Auvergne said that if the policies were pursued, his country faced being pushed into what he called the "abyss of unemployment, poverty, hunger and social chaos."
"Nice words, platitudes, promises and insincere expressions of concern will not solve the problems of hunger," he said. "Nor will they meet the objectives of this summit."
